<li><b>Axe Mastery:</b> Kratos is extremely skilled with wielding an axe in combat, with him wielding Faye's <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_Axe" title="Leviathan Axe">Leviathan Axe</a> with devastating proficiency to skillfully kill numerous monsters. At one point, Kratos was able to kill off Magni with a series of precise blows at fatal spots in a matter of moments. He was even able to successfully wield the Leviathan Axe against Thor and his usage of Mjölnir, fulfilling the purpose of Leviathan's creation, managing to overwhelm Thor enough to finally make him draw his hammer and eventually best and disarm Thor of his hammer with the Axe in their final duel, and managed to impale Odin in the shoulder with the axe.</li>
<li><b>Chain Mastery:</b> Kratos is exceedingly skilled in the manipulation of chained weaponry such as the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a>; his trademark weapon, the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Athena" title="Blades of Athena">Blades of Athena</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Claws_of_Hades" title="Claws of Hades">Claws of Hades</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Nemesis_Whip" title="Nemesis Whip">Nemesis Whip</a>, with great precision and proficiency to devastatingly assault his foes over any distance and at high-speed, use them as a means to swing over chasms and also use them as a restraint on his foes.</li>
<li><b>Shield Mastery:</b> Kratos is exceptionally skilled in using a shield, as demonstrated with his <a href="/wiki/Guardian_Shield" title="Guardian Shield">Guardian Shield</a>, masterfully using it for numerous purposes, such as effectively defending against numerous projectiles or close-range attacks and even able to use it offensively, skillfully countering close-range attacks and delivering numerous attacks.</li>
<li><b>Spear Mastery</b>: Kratos is also exceptionally skilled at wielding spears in combat, having wielded the <a href="/wiki/Spear_of_Destiny" title="Spear of Destiny">Spear of Destiny</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arms_of_Sparta" title="Arms of Sparta">Arms of Sparta</a> with great skill. Upon receiving the <a href="/wiki/Draupnir_Spear" title="Draupnir Spear">Draupnir Spear</a>, a magic ring which creates limitless amount of its namesake spears, his skill proved to be still as sharp of ever, able to use the spear to successfully overpower Heimdall in combat and even match Odin's own in their fateful confrontation.</li>
<li><b>Master Marksman:</b> He is also a highly skilled marksman, capable of using ranged weapons (throwing weapons and bows) with devastating ease and proficiency. He is also able to apply his marksmanship with the Leviathan Axe, as he can throw it at his target and can summon it back to him.</li>
<li><figure class="thumb mw-halign-left show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/1d/Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20221219225004" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="Kratos fighting a Gulon" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Kratos fighting a Gulon.jpg" data-image-key="Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/1d/Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20221219225004"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/1d/Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20221219225004" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Kratos fighting a Gulon" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/1d/Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20221219225004" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Kratos fighting a Gulon.jpg" data-image-key="Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/1d/Kratos_fighting_a_Gulon.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20221219225004"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 	</figcaption> </figure><b>Master Hand-to-Hand Combatant</b>: Although primarily using weapons, Kratos is also an exceptional martial artist and hand-to-hand combatant, proficient in numerous techniques of Greek wrestling, boxing, and Pankration, able to skillfully wrestle and throw down enemies and unleash fast-paced barrages of uppercuts, punches, kicks, elbow strikes, knee strikes, and spinning haymakers that can easily and quickly overwhelm most opponents. His unarmed fighting skills can easily subdue even powerful monsters and multiple opponents, even at one point dispatching numerous <a href="/wiki/Asgardians" title="Asgardians">Asgardian</a> soldiers with a single hand while the other was carrying <a href="/wiki/Freyr" title="Freyr">Freyr</a>. Even without weapons, Kratos was able to defeat the extremely skilled hand-to-hand fighter Baldur in single combat thrice, although not without extreme effort and being initially pressured by his skill, as well as battle back Thor in unarmed combat, managing to maneuver out of Thor's grip and deliver numerous blows on him, even at one point gaining the upper hand and pummeling him decisively for a short moment. He also easily disarmed and bested Modi while enraged, and even overpowered Freya using solely his skill in unarmed combat, reversing her hold on him, delivering attacks that knocked her off him when she tried to break his neck, and even disarming her of her sword at their final exchange, all while having the use of only one hand. Kratos even outmaneuvered Odin in the final battle against him unarmed, lifting and tossing him aside and helping Freya and Atreus swiftly beat him down.</li></ul></li>
<li><b>Master Swimmer:</b> Kratos, thanks to his superhuman strength and stamina, is a skilled swimmer, capable of swimming at great distances and going underwater to reach his destinations.</li></ul>
<h4><span id="Bestowed_Abilities_.28Greece.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bestowed_Abilities_(Greece)">Bestowed Abilities (Greece)</span></h4>
<ul><li><b>Poseidon's Rage:</b> Harnessing the power of sea storms, Kratos can vaporize his enemies with powerful streams of lightning.</li>
<li><b>Medusa's Gaze:</b> Torn from the Gorgon Queen's serpentine body, Kratos can harness the power of Medusa's head to turn his enemies to solid stone.</li>
<li><b>Zeus' Fury:</b> Granted to him by the King of the Gods himself, Kratos can hurl thunderbolts at his enemies from afar. Can be charged for a devastating blast of lightning.</li>
<li><b>Army of Hades:</b> The God of the Underworld granted Kratos command of the Dead. Kratos summons invincible vicious warrior spirits to tear his enemies to shreds. Ares himself could not withstand such an assault.</li>
<li><b>Rage of the Gods:</b> Granted to him by the Goddess Athena, Kratos could focus his rage and power to give himself godlike powers, becoming invincible and granted infinite power (magic), but only for a short time.</li>
<li><b>Typhon's Bane:</b> Torn from the eye of the imprisoned Titan, Typhon, this ability manifested into the shape of a bow. Kratos could harness the power of wind to fire blasts of wind or create small tornadoes.</li>
<li><b>Cronos' Rage:</b> Before his fall in the Great War with the Gods, Cronos, the leader of the Titans hid away the last of his magic. Granted to Kratos, he could place orbs of electricity that would electrocute anything nearby and explode.</li>
<li><b>Euryales Gaze:</b> Torn from the body of Medusa's sister Euryale, Kratos can use the Gorgon's head much like the Medusa's Gaze.</li>
<li><b>Atlas Quake:</b> Granted to him by the mighty Titan Atlas, Kratos can pound the earth with his fists to send shock waves of debris in all directions.</li>
<li><b>Rage of the Titans:</b> By freeing Prometheus and allowing him to be consumed in fire, his ashes, tainted with the power of the Titans, have been given to Kratos and allow him control of fire as well as making his durability and speed go up.</li>
<li><b>Efreet:</b> By summoning the Fire Demon Efreet, Kratos can command it to pound the ground with its fists and burn enemies in the process.</li>
<li><b>Light of Dawn:</b> Drawing power from light itself, Kratos can create orbs of light and force and hurl them at his enemies.</li>
<li><b>Charon's Wrath:</b> With the mask of the ferryman of the Underworld, Kratos can send forth a blast of green flame that will slowly end the life of those it touches.</li>
<li><b>Divine Reckoning:</b> With the Blade of Olympus in hand, Kratos can plunge the weapon into the ground and envelop himself in a vortex of energy that decimates nearby enemies.</li>
<li><b>Army of Sparta:</b> Calling forth the spirits of his Spartan comrades, Kratos can command them to form an impenetrable phalanx around him and attack his enemies with spears and a rain of arrows.</li>
<li><b>Soul Summon:</b> Harnessing the power of the Claws of Hades, Kratos can call forth various ethereal beasts to attack his enemies.</li>
<li><b>Nemean Roar:</b> By slamming the Nemean Cestus into the ground, Kratos can send forth a barrage of powerful shockwaves.</li>
<li><b>Nemesis Rage:</b> Using the Nemesis Whips, Kratos can send forth a surge of electric energy that will attach to an enemy and attack others as well.</li>
<li><b>Rage of Sparta:</b> By drawing upon the power of the Blade of Olympus, Kratos can become temporarily invulnerable and move at greater speeds.</li></ul>
<h4><span id="Bestowed_Abilities_.28Norse.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bestowed_Abilities_(Norse)">Bestowed Abilities (Norse)</span></h4>
<ul><li><b>Aegir's Protection:</b> Creates a temporary circular defensive zone that prevents Kratos' attacks from being interrupted while reducing the amount of damage he takes. Restores a small amount of health.</li>
<li><b>The Charm of Infinite Storms:</b> Summons a storm of ice that prevents Kratos’ attacks from being interrupted, reduces the amount of damage he takes and inflicts normal and Frost damage to all nearby enemies.</li>
<li><b>Talisman of Cursed Power:</b> Unleashes a wave of Cursed Mist that instantly weakens all surrounding enemies by lowering all of their Stats.</li>
<li><b>Talisman of the Realms:</b> Summons a Realm Shift that slows down all nearby enemies.</li>
<li><b>Shattered Gauntlet of the Ages:</b> An ancient relic of Hel deemed too powerful to remain whole. When enhanced with at least 3 of 6 mystical gems, becomes capable of releasing a powerful blast of energy.</li>
<li><b>Eye of the Outer Realm:</b> Increases overall Stats.</li>
<li><b>Andvari's Soul:</b> The soul of the Dwarf Andvari, with which Atreus can seemingly communicate. Grants a high activation chance of a Health Burst on any Runic Attack kill.</li>
<li><b>Nörd's Temporal Stone:</b> Grants a low activation chance of triggering a Realm Shift after taking damage.</li>
<li><b>Ivaldi's Corrupted Mind:</b> The twisted mind of the Dwarven alchemist Ivaldi contained within a gemstone. All nearby enemies within 15 meters are weakened, lowering their overall stats.</li>
<li><b>Muspelheim Eye of Power:</b> Increases overall Stats and grants resistance to Burn damage.</li>
<li><b>Asgard's Shard of Existence:</b> Charging up the Enchantment for a few seconds grants Fortification, causing an explosive knockback on the next successful block.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Weapons">Weapons</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Greek_Era">Greek Era</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a>
</p><p>The <b>Blades of Chaos</b> were forged at the darkest depths of the <a href="/wiki/Underworld" title="Underworld">Underworld</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ares" title="Ares">Ares</a> himself. They were imbued with <a href="/wiki/Primordial_Fire" title="Primordial Fire">Primordial Fire</a>, which allowed them to ignite with every attack that the user performed. The blades' chains would stretch out for a set distance with each attack, allowing for fluid movement no matter who wielded them. The chains of the blades were permanently seared onto the forearms of the wielder, which served as a reminder of their oath to the <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(God)" title="God of War (God)">God of War</a>, and could only be removed either by the "<b>God of War</b>" himself or when the wielder's time of servitude ended. However, when their creator is dead with the servant still owning them, they can be removed or equipped, whenever needed.
</p><p>After Kratos pledged his life to the God of War, Ares had his Harpies fetch the Blades of Chaos and bestowed them on the <a href="/wiki/Spartan" title="Spartan">Spartan</a>, claiming they were weapons truly worthy of a God's champion. After Ares decimated the <a href="/wiki/Barbarians" title="Barbarians">Barbarian</a> forces, Kratos used his new weapons to slay the Barbarian King, <a href="/wiki/Alrik" title="Alrik">Alrik</a>, in single combat. Kratos continued to utilize the blades during his time of servitude to Ares and the <a href="/wiki/Gods" title="Gods">Gods</a> - even against his own wife, <a href="/wiki/Lysandra" title="Lysandra">Lysandra</a>, and daughter <a href="/wiki/Calliope" title="Calliope">Calliope</a>, whom he unknowingly killed while he was in a god-driven rage that was set by Ares.
</p><p>Kratos, at the peak of his task to kill the God of War, had the Blades of Chaos stripped away from him after he defended his family in one of Ares' Illusions. With the blades taken away from him, Ares manipulated the blades to once more kill Kratos' family, while a helpless Kratos watched in horror. After the fall of Ares, the blades were never seen again, but Kratos was soon granted the similar <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Athena" title="Blades of Athena">Blades of Athena</a>. After killing Ares and taking his place as the God of War, Kratos gained all of Ares' weapons, including the Blades of Chaos. Although, he vowed never to use them again.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Athena" title="Blades of Athena">Blades of Athena</a>
</p><p>The <b>Blades of Athena</b> were a pair chained weaponry that were bestowed to Kratos by <a href="/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a> after he killed <a href="/wiki/Ares" title="Ares">Ares</a>. They were the second pair of blades that Kratos wielded. Also known as "<b>Athena's Blades</b>", this weapon were seemingly identical to the Blades of Chaos when Kratos first received them. The blades also had the same abilities as the Blades of Chaos.
</p><p>While Kratos was a God, the Blades of Athena gave off a yellow aura and were gold in color with blue-colored Glyphs due to the godly magic that emanated from them. After Kratos drained the remainder of his godly powers into the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>, they reverted to their basic form with a steel color and a faint yellow aura.
</p><p>They were then leveled up much like the Blades of Chaos and gradually regained their gold color. From its final level, they emitted a red flaming glow and the glyphs became red in color. However, when Kratos fell into the <a href="/wiki/River_Styx" title="River Styx">River Styx</a>, the blades were destroyed and rusted. Afterwards, the <a href="/wiki/Astral_Form" title="Astral Form">Astral Form</a> of Athena took the ruined blades and transformed them into the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>
</p><p>The <b>Blades of Exile</b> were the third and last set of chained blades that were wielded by Kratos and were given to him by the <a href="/wiki/Astral_Form" title="Astral Form">Astral Form</a> of <a href="/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a> at <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_III" title="God of War III">God of War III</a></i>. The blades replaced the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Athena" title="Blades of Athena">Blades of Athena</a> as Kratos' primary weapons, as the latter, which he received upon his rise to <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(God)" title="God of War (God)">God of War</a>, were thoroughly rusted and destroyed by his fall into the <a href="/wiki/River_Styx" title="River Styx">River Styx</a>. The Blades of Exile also had a slightly different design, but their model did not change as they leveled up with the only exception being the amount of, "flames," that the blades emitted when they were in use.
</p><p>The blades had attack patterns that were similar to their predecessors, the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a> and of Athena, but with distinctly different designs. The blades' primary features include tormented demonic-like faces with horn-like curved spikes that appeared out of the, "heads," on the hilts, pronounced hooks on their lower edges, and an intricate pattern of shimmering orange stripes on the flat sides of the blades, which emitted fire whenever they were swung. The Blades of Exile granted Kratos the magic power, <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Sparta" title="Army of Sparta">Army of Sparta</a>, as well as the ability to grapple enemies.
</p><p>The Blades of Exile were one of the only three weapons that were not destroyed by Zeus after he rose from his body in his Astral Form and attacked Kratos. It was unknown what happened to the Blades of Exile after Kratos impaled himself with the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>. They were last seen discarded by Kratos after he had forced <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a>' soul back into his body. Though considering how the chains on Kratos' arms were loosened upon Zeus' death, it could simply be implied that he no longer had use for the blades and their main purpose was complete.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Artemis" title="Blade of Artemis">Blade of Artemis</a>
</p><p>The <b>Blade of Artemis</b> was a large, curved blade that was utilized with both hands, and was formerly used by <a href="/wiki/Artemis" title="Artemis">Artemis</a>. It was once used by Artemis to slay a <a href="/wiki/Titans" title="Titans">Titan</a>. Artemis gave it to Kratos shortly after he entered <a href="/wiki/Pandora%27s_Temple" title="Pandora's Temple">Pandora's Temple</a>. Surrounded by raw energies, the blade was capable of piercing armor and could easily damage any enemy.
</p><p>It could then be leveled up to further increase damage, which also changed its energy <a href="/wiki/Colors" title="Colors">color.</a> Kratos used the blade even after he became the new <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(God)" title="God of War (God)">God of War</a>, as seen in <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Betrayal" title="God of War: Betrayal">God of War: Betrayal</a></i>. However, during <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_II" title="God of War II"><i>God of War II</i></a>, Kratos did not wield the Blade of Artemis anymore.
</p><p>The weapon made no appearance in <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Ghost_of_Sparta" title="God of War: Ghost of Sparta">Ghost of Sparta</a></i>, though the game took place soon after <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War" class="mw-redirect" title="God of War">God of War (2005)</a></i>. It was likely that Artemis took back her blade after the events of <i>God of War (2005)</i>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>
</p><p>The <b>Blade of Olympus</b> itself was a large golden and white metal blade with bluish hues of energy that brimmed through and around it. Also, the weapon was created in the First Titanomachy by <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> as means to end the war. After the defeat of <a href="/wiki/Atlas" title="Atlas">Atlas</a>, Zeus returned to the battlefield and wielded his new weapon. He pushed the blade into Earth and chanted that he banished the Titans to the depths of Tartarus.
</p><p>The weapon was seen again in <a href="/wiki/Rhodes" title="Rhodes">Rhodes</a>, when Zeus sent it down for Kratos to help him destroy the <a href="/wiki/Colossus_of_Rhodes" title="Colossus of Rhodes">Colossus of Rhodes</a>. But, as the collapsing Colossus of Rhodes' hand crashed down on Kratos, it appeared that he was severely weakened by giving his power to the blade. Beatened up, Kratos tried to regain the blade, only for Zeus to arrived and retrieved it, and thus prevented Kratos from regaining his powers. Zeus then shoved the blade into Kratos' abdomen, which brought him to the verge of death, and sent him to the <a href="/wiki/Underworld" title="Underworld">Underworld</a>. Later, Kratos regained the Blade of Olympus after he went back through time and with it, he fought and nearly killed Zeus on the <a href="/wiki/Summit_of_Sacrifice" title="Summit of Sacrifice">Summit of Sacrifice</a>. Kratos, who intended to thrust the blade through Zeus' chest, invoked <a href="/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a>'s interference, and killed her instead of Zeus.
</p><p>The Blade of Olympus also appeared in <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_III" title="God of War III">God of War III</a></i>, as Kratos planted the blade on top of <a href="/wiki/Gaia" title="Gaia">Gaia</a>'s back during the Titans' siege of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Mount Olympus</a>. When both he and Gaia were thrown off of Olympus, Kratos wedged it into Gaia in an attempt to hold on, but both he and the blade fell into the Underworld. Later, when Kratos retrieved the blade from a <a href="/wiki/Pandora_Statues" title="Pandora Statues">Statue of Pandora</a> in the depths of Hades, he was able to use it as a part of the Rage of Sparta. The Rage of Sparta was the only means by which he used the Blade of Olympus. Nonetheless, the blade proved quite useful and strong in defeating some of the major opponents that were encountered over the course of his journey. It was used to slay <a href="/wiki/Cronos" title="Cronos">Cronos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perses" title="Perses">Perses</a> as Kratos journeyed through the Underworld and Olympus, and in the final battle, it was used to kill both Zeus and Gaia. In the very end, Kratos ultimately used the blade to stab himself, and thus, released the power of <a href="/wiki/Hope" title="Hope">Hope</a> that dwelt within him, as well as the power within the blade itself, which was rendered useless. The Blade of Olympus was last seen in the ground of <a href="/wiki/Zeus%27_Battle_Arena" title="Zeus' Battle Arena">Zeus' Battle Arena</a>, abandoned, following Kratos' disappearance from Olympus.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Barbarian_Hammer" title="Barbarian Hammer">Barbarian Hammer</a>
</p><p>The <b>Barbarian Hammer</b> is a slow, but powerful melee weapon originally wielded by the Barbarian King, <a href="/wiki/Alrik" title="Alrik">Alrik</a>. Kratos could deliver powerful slams and smashes. The hammer itself is large, bloodied, and spiked, that also had the ability to summon <a href="/wiki/Cursed_Souls" title="Cursed Souls">Cursed Souls</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Underworld" title="Underworld">Underworld</a>. It was extremely useful in situations where multiple enemies were approaching, as one or two blows by the hammer could kill them in an instant. By leveling up the Barbarian Hammer, it could increase its damage power, and gained new abilities for it. Although slow and heavy in use, the Barbarian Hammer was, statistically speaking, the most powerful melee weapon, next to the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Claws_of_Hades" title="Claws of Hades">Claws of Hades</a>
</p><p>The <b>Claws of Hades</b> were a pair of chained weapons formerly utilized by <a href="/wiki/Hades" title="Hades">Hades</a>. They were later procured by Kratos after Hades' death. During both of the Great Wars, Hades could be seen fighting with this weapons. They were depicted as a set of spiked chains with two hooks at the end of each that glowed pale purple. Hades was "draped" in them, and they were embodied with his magic <a href="/wiki/Powers" title="Powers">powers</a>. Using the magic stored within the chains, Hades could pull out the soul of his enemies.
</p><p>This was also seen in one of the cutscenes in <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_II" title="God of War II">God of War II</a></i>, where Hades ripped out the soul of <a href="/wiki/Atlas" title="Atlas">Atlas</a> and absorbed it. Those chains were extremely lethal weapons as they allowed Hades to attack at short and long distances. They glowed with a dark purplish aura that indicated the number of souls it absorbed. By absorbing countless souls, the chains' attack power increased as well as speed. Hades had the ability to summon Legions of the Undead as well as a wide array of Undead Beasts by using the claws' power. The chains were a very powerful part of Hades' arsenal, and, with them, defeated many <a href="/wiki/Titans" title="Titans">Titans</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Titanomachy" title="Titanomachy">Titanomachy</a>.
</p><p>In <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_III" title="God of War III">God of War III</a></i>, Kratos used this weapons after he took them from Hades. The claws allowed Kratos to summon the souls of the undead. With them, Kratos could rip the souls out of his enemies and they then would attack the other enemies. They had an attack that was similar to the <a href="/wiki/Barbarian_Hammer" title="Barbarian Hammer">Barbarian Hammer</a> which allowed Kratos to summon souls of the enemies he fought in order to occupy them. A soul could be selected in the power up menu out of a selection of beasts that Kratos encountered on his quest. The Claws of Hades were later destroyed by <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a>' <a href="/wiki/Astral_Form" title="Astral Form">Astral Form</a> along with the rest of <a href="/wiki/Kratos%27_Equipment" title="Kratos' Equipment">Kratos' Equipment</a> excluding the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Boots_of_Hermes" title="Boots of Hermes">Boots of Hermes</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nemean_Cestus" title="Nemean Cestus">Nemean Cestus</a>
</p><p>The <b>Nemean Cestus</b> were a pair of large metal gauntlets, each forged that resembled a snarling lion's head, that greatly increased the strength of its wielder when they were worn. They were also similar to the <a href="/wiki/Claws_of_Hades" title="Claws of Hades">Claws of Hades</a>. With each strike, a sound of a lion roaring/growling could be heard slightly.
</p><p>During Hercules' fight with Kratos, the former donned the Cestus as he engaged the <a href="/wiki/Spartan" title="Spartan">Spartan</a> in battle. However, the Cestus were forcefully taken from him, and Kratos used them to batter his half-brother to death. The Nemean Cestus was the only weapon that was able to destroy <a href="/wiki/Onyx" title="Onyx">Onyx</a>, a type of rock that frequently appeared in <i>God of War III</i>, in the form of shields, walls, and armor. They were also the only weapon that was capable of killing <a href="/wiki/Skorpius" title="Skorpius">Skorpius</a>, as the creature's body was armored with Onyx.
</p><p>The Cestus even proved useful against the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Talos" title="Bronze Talos">Bronze Talos</a> and, when fully upgraded, against the King of the <a href="/wiki/Gods" title="Gods">Gods</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a>. Like most of Kratos' Weapons, except for the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Boots_of_Hermes" title="Boots of Hermes">Boots of Hermes</a>, the Nemean Cestus was destroyed by Zeus' <a href="/wiki/Astral_Form" title="Astral Form">Astral Form</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nemesis_Whip" title="Nemesis Whip">Nemesis Whip</a>
</p><p>The <b>Nemesis Whip</b> consisted of a pair of chains, each ending in three claw-like daggers that gave off a teal <a href="/wiki/Colors" title="Colors">colored</a> aura. It was crafted for Kratos by <a href="/wiki/Hephaestus" title="Hephaestus">Hephaestus</a> after he brought him the <a href="/wiki/Omphalos_Stone" title="Omphalos Stone">Omphalos Stone</a>, a decoy that <a href="/wiki/Cronos" title="Cronos">Cronos</a> originally mistook for baby <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> and swallowed many years ago. Initially, Hephaestus intended to use them as a conduit for his own powers in order to kill Kratos, but the <a href="/wiki/Spartan" title="Spartan">Spartan</a> threw off the attack, turned the Whip against its creator, and killed the God of Smith.
</p><p>The weapon is attacked in a similar fashion to the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>, but were faster and weaker, with a focus on multiple hits instead of single, powerful blows. It had the power to conduct electricity and electrocute whomever stood in Kratos’ way. The whips were useful when they were leveled up to recharge the <a href="/wiki/Rage_of_Sparta" title="Rage of Sparta">Rage of Sparta</a> while fighting opponents.
</p><p>Despite the weak power per hit, unlike other weapons, the launch attack does not require "hold button" input, making it the quickest weapon in terms of throwing launch-able airborne. Combine with the range, the Nemesis Whip possess a superior capability in counterattacks and setting up enemies for combo, making it the most effective weapon against elite and agile enemies that can block/parry, such as the Satyr, Siren and Elite Minotaur.
</p><p>Like most of Kratos' Weapons, excluding the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Boots_of_Hermes" title="Boots of Hermes">Boots of Hermes</a>, the Nemesis Whip was destroyed by Zeus' <a href="/wiki/Astral_Form" title="Astral Form">Astral Form</a> during his final attempt to defeat Kratos.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Spear_of_Destiny" title="Spear of Destiny">Spear of Destiny</a>
</p><p>The <b>Spear of Destiny</b> will be later wielded upon by Kratos on <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_II" title="God of War II">God of War II</a></i> as he is on his way to the <a href="/wiki/Titans" title="Titans">Titan</a> <a href="/wiki/Typhon" title="Typhon">Typhon</a>, because before he arrived at the <a href="/wiki/Island_of_Creation" title="Island of Creation">Island of Creation</a>, a Dark <a href="/wiki/Dark_Rider" title="Dark Rider">Rider</a> appeared and attacks him with the spear. Kratos then jumped onto the Dark <a href="/wiki/Dark_Griffin" title="Dark Griffin">Griffin</a> after he jumped off to <a href="/wiki/Pegasus" title="Pegasus">Pegasus</a> and counterattacked the Dark Rider. Kratos stabbed him numerous times and took the Spear of Destiny. From there, Kratos speared the Dark Griffin and chopped its wings off, which sent it crashing to the ground.
</p><p>Because the weapon is now wielded by Kratos, he could perform deadly swipes and stabs, and could also fire dangerous piercing projectiles at enemies. Furthermore, the spear can create purple crystals that were infused in its ends, which could be used to pierce enemies and even created more explosive crystals. It also had the ability to extend and retract itself for greater range attacks.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Norse_Era">Norse Era</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Leviathan_Axe" title="Leviathan Axe">Leviathan Axe</a>
</p><p>The <b>Leviathan Axe</b> is a magical axe which was originally owned by <a href="/wiki/Faye" class="mw-redirect" title="Faye">Faye</a>, the mother of his future son, <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a>. The axe has the properties of ice magic as swinging its blade creates light blue energy waves, which can be charged up, and hitting the ground freezes enemies close to impact. Kratos also throws the axe directly towards opponents in battle and it seems that it can return to his hand by raising it but only for a limited range. The Leviathan Axe's ice magic is very effective against enemies with the attribute of Burn, while the fiery swing of the blades damage effectively those of Frost. After meeting with <a href="/wiki/Brok" title="Brok">Brok</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sindri" title="Sindri">Sindri</a>, gem slots called <a href="/wiki/Runic_Attacks_(Ragnar%C3%B6k)" title="Runic Attacks (Ragnarök)">Runic Attacks</a> are given on each weapon's head that modifies the axe's and the blades' abilities.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Guardian_Shield" title="Guardian Shield">Guardian Shield</a>
</p><p>The <b>Guardian Shield</b> is a golden circular shield attached to a golden gauntlet in Kratos' arm that he uses both offensively and defensively. He wears it like a brace for his left forearm but it instantly retracts to its full form at will. He is shown to pair this with his axe or his left <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blade of Chaos</a> in battle. He can infuse the magical abilities of his <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_Axe" title="Leviathan Axe">Leviathan Axe</a> and the fire of his left Blade of Chaos into the shield, allowing for more explosive and devastating combos. And he is able to parry with the shield, managing to deflect enemy projectiles back at them.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kratos%27_Knife" title="Kratos' Knife">Kratos' Knife</a>
</p><p>The <b>Knife of Kratos</b> was crafted by the "<b>God of War</b>" himself and it is used during his travels throughout the Northlands. He forged the knife, mixing metals from his homeland and metals from the lands that they were currently in. This is one of two knives that he possessed, the other belonging to <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a>, "<b>Champion of the Jötnar</b>".
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a>
</p><p>The <b>Blades of Chaos</b> were found again by Kratos himself in the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Egypt</a> Realm and brought them with him to the <a href="/wiki/Nine_Realms" title="Nine Realms">Norse</a> Realm, where he hid them, wrapped together in a thick red cloth with a simple <a href="/wiki/Greek_World" title="Greek World">Grecian</a> Pattern on it, under the floorboards of his <a href="/wiki/Kratos%27_Cabin" title="Kratos' Cabin">Cabin</a>, hoping never to use them again. He explains why he kept the Blades of Chaos, despite his painful history, as he could not be rid of them at all; the Blades always found their way back to him under the most contrived circumstances. For example, he tried to dump them in the ocean but the sea itself rejected them and destroyed his boat. He washed up ashore with the blades next to him. After this incident, he gave up and hid them beneath the floorboards as a forced reminder of his tragic history and explosive rage.
</p><p>Eventually, however, Kratos' son falls ill due to the conflicting natures within him. Learning that the main ingredient needed to treat <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a> was in <a href="/wiki/Helheim" title="Helheim">Helheim</a>—where the ice magic of the <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_Axe" title="Leviathan Axe">Leviathan Axe</a> was useless due to the unyielding cold of the realm as no enemy can be killed with such weapon—Kratos retrieved the blades from their hiding place and grimly rebound their chains to his forearms in order to use them once more. An opposed to the ice-aspected Leviathan Axe, the blades give off the element of fire. Once upgraded progressively, the blades change gradually in appearance, restoring the cracked Greek blades into a more Nordic style, adding Nordic glyphs similar to the Leviathan Axe.
</p><p>These Glyphs glow fiery orange when ignited, and small runes written in old Nordic decorate the edges of each blade. The hilts become gold in color and gain two slots on the skulls' eyes for <a href="/wiki/Runic_Attacks_(2018)" title="Runic Attacks (2018)">Runic Attacks</a>; one for light and one for heavy, while also allowing Kratos to change the pommels for different attributes. Kratos can also infuse the fire of his left blade to his <a href="/wiki/Guardian_Shield" title="Guardian Shield">Guardian Shield</a>, before slamming it to his foes, dealing massive damage. The blades, via a <a href="/wiki/Runic_Attacks_(2018)" title="Runic Attacks (2018)">Runic Attack</a> called <a href="/wiki/Meteoric_Slam_(Runic_Attack)" title="Meteoric Slam (Runic Attack)">Meteoric Slam</a>, can summon a meteor shower of fire that deals Burn damage to enemies. After meeting <a href="/wiki/Brok" title="Brok">Brok</a> in Helheim, the Blades were also upgraded to temporarily channel energy known as the <a href="/wiki/Hel" title="Hel">Winds of Hel</a>. Additionally, each upgrade was accompanied by an increasingly more intricate motif of a Serpent or Dragon just beneath the blade.
</p><p>By the time <i><a href="/wiki/Ragnar%C3%B6k" title="Ragnarök">Ragnarök</a></i> begins, the magic-weakening effects of <a href="/wiki/Fimbulwinter" title="Fimbulwinter">Fimbulwinter</a> had reverted the Blades of Chaos back to their cracked, rusted state. However, like before, Brok and Sindri (and later on <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BAnda" title="Lúnda">Lúnda</a>) were able to upgrade the blades once again by using <a href="/wiki/Chaos_Flame" title="Chaos Flame">Chaos Flames</a>. The skull design of the blades’ hilts undergoes a drastic transformation, bearing a more Nordic motif than their original form. When fully upgraded, the flat surfaces of the blades are outlined with gold, most intricately along the very edge of the blade, and the glyphs become golden as well. Along with this, Kratos also uses the blades as a means of climbing and maneuvering high cliffs, as well as pulling down certain blockades.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Surtr" title="Surtr">Surtr</a>, the first Fire <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tnar" title="Jötnar">Giant</a>, sensed the Primordial Fire within the Blades of Chaos, and while the fire was from a foreign realm, Surtr believed that their origin should not matter and would be essential in turning him Ragnarök without the need to sacrifice <a href="/wiki/Sinmara" title="Sinmara">Sinmara</a>. When reaching the <a href="/wiki/Spark_of_the_World" title="Spark of the World">Spark of the World</a>, Surtr imbued his fire to the Blades of Chaos and through them caused some pain to both Surtr and Kratos. Following Surtr's instructions, Kratos used his blades to stab Sinmara's heart within Surtr's body, empowering the first Fire Giant to become Ragnarök
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Draupnir_Spear" title="Draupnir Spear">Draupnir Spear</a>
</p><p>The <b>Draupnir Spear</b> is a golden magical spear that was forged by The <a href="/wiki/The_Lady_of_the_Forge" title="The Lady of the Forge">Lady of the Forge</a> with Kratos’ blood for the sole purpose of killing the Æsir threat, <a href="/wiki/Heimdall" title="Heimdall">Heimdall</a>. He wears it as a ring on his right hand but it can be summoned at will. The spear has the ability to near-infinitely create spear duplicates that can be thrown and detonated by slamming the butt of the spear into the ground. It also has properties of wind magic, which allows it to draw in enemies and blast them back a good distance away. Kratos can also absorb elemental attributes from enemies using the spear and use it against them for a limited time.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Gram" title="Gram">Gram</a>
</p><p><b>Gram</b> (Old Norse: <b>Wrath</b>) is a relic that can be found in the Temple of Light in Alfheim. It is a powerful sword that is possibly well known for being used to slay dragons, hence its alias <b>The Dragon's Bane</b>. Gram is proven to be powerful and superior because in the <i>Norse Mythology</i>, it had accomplished many feats, but one of the feats that is well-known is slaying different dragons.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ridill" title="Ridill">Ridill</a>
</p><p><b>Ridill</b>, or <b>Riðill</b>, is the sword of the <a href="/wiki/Dwarf" class="mw-redirect" title="Dwarf">Dwarf</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Dragon" class="mw-redirect" title="Dragon">Dragon</a>) <a href="/wiki/Reginn" title="Reginn">Reginn</a>. It is one of the many usable relics that Kratos can use. In <i>Norse Mythology</i>, the sword was used to cut out many hearts and it is owned by Regin, a dwarf. When pronounced and spoken out-loud, it sounds almost identical to the word <b>Riddle</b>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hrotti" title="Hrotti">Hrotti</a>
</p><p><b>Hrotti</b> is a relic and magical sword that used to be part of <a href="/wiki/Fafnir" title="Fafnir">Fafnir</a>'s treasure until it was stolen from the dwarf's treasure vault. Kratos can obtain the Hilt of Hrotti by venturing to the Plains region of the Vanaheim Crater, and dispatching the Oath Guards (<a href="/wiki/J%C3%B8rgen_The_Oath_Guard" title="Jørgen The Oath Guard">Jørgen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vali_The_Oath_Guard" title="Vali The Oath Guard">Vali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egil_The_Oath_Guard" title="Egil The Oath Guard">Egil</a>), three <a href="/wiki/Travelers" title="Travelers">Travelers</a> who are trying to locate and assassinate <a href="/wiki/Birgir" title="Birgir">Birgir</a> for heresy. Kratos can kill the Oath Guards in any order he wishes, the second of whom drops the hilt upon death.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tyrfing" title="Tyrfing">Tyrfing</a>
</p><p><b>Tyrfing</b> is a magical sword that has a long and "bloody history". It is one of the sword relics whom Kratos can use in battle. A type of sword with a golden hilt that would never miss a stroke, would never rust, and even cut through rock and iron. When Tyrfing was finally finished, it gleams brightly and shone like fire. However, the sword was bestowed with a curse so that every time it is drawn, it will easily kill anyone on its path.  
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Skofnung" title="Skofnung">Skofnung</a>
</p><p>The <b>Skofnung</b> is a sword that was once wielded by <a href="/wiki/King_Hr%C3%B3lf_Kraki" title="King Hrólf Kraki">King Hrólf Kraki</a>, the King of <a href="/wiki/Berserkers" title="Berserkers">Berserkers</a>. Once known as the sharpest sword in <a href="/wiki/Midgard" title="Midgard">Midgard</a>, the hilt was used to contain the souls of the twelve (12) <a href="/wiki/Berserkers" title="Berserkers">Berserkers</a>. Eventually, the hilt was found by Kratos. During the battle against Hrólf Kraki, Kratos managed to weaken and decapitate him. After the Berserker King’s death, Kratos kept the sword and vowed to use it for good from then on.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Equipments">Equipments</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Greek_Period">Greek Period</span></h3>
<ul><li><b>Magic Pouch:</b> Another signature item for Kratos which he carries since his time as a general for <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a>. He can carry numerous equipment or weapons and take them out just by reaching into it while thinking about the chosen item. This pouch is able to carry things much as big as Kratos himself and wears it under his loincloth. Because of this, Kratos also carried many other powerful weapons or relics throughout the series, some of which include the <a href="/wiki/Barbarian_Hammer" title="Barbarian Hammer">Barbarian Hammer</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nemean_Cestus" title="Nemean Cestus">Nemean Cestus</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Artemis" title="Blade of Artemis">Blade of Artemis</a> etc.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Poseidon%27s_Trident" title="Poseidon's Trident"><b>Poseidon's Trident</b></a>: Grants Kratos the ability to breathe underwater indefinitely.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Amulet_of_the_Fates" title="Amulet of the Fates"><b>Amulet of the Fates</b></a>: Is only used near certain statues, where Kratos can move through time while all around him slows.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Golden_Fleece" title="Golden Fleece"><b>Golden Fleece</b></a>: an indestructible piece of armor for the wearer's arm. It has the ability to catch incoming enemy projectiles and send them back to the enemy.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Icarus_Wings" title="Icarus Wings"><b>Icarus' Wings</b></a>: They were torn apart by Kratos from the legendary <a href="/wiki/Icarus" title="Icarus">Icarus</a>, Kratos can use the artificial wings to glide and fly with the help of powerful upward drafts.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sun_Shield" title="Sun Shield"><b>Sun Shield</b></a>: It originally belongs to <a href="/wiki/Helios" title="Helios">Helios</a>, the God of the Sun. This shield can block enemy attacks and projectiles.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Triton%27s_Lance" title="Triton's Lance"><b>Triton's Lance</b></a>: Helps Kratos swim, dive, and breathe underwater indefinitely.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bow_of_Apollo" title="Bow of Apollo"><b>Bow of Apollo</b></a>: a magical bow that can fire an infinite amount of flaming arrows. Can set objects and enemies on fire.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Head_of_Helios" title="Head of Helios"><b>Head of Helios</b></a>: Torn by the God of War himself, Kratos. He can harness the power of Helios' head to illuminate his way through dark areas and even damage his enemies with powerful surges of light.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Boots_of_Hermes" title="Boots of Hermes"><b>Boots of Hermes</b></a>: They were a pair of winged sandals. It was taken by Kratos from Helios. With the source of the God of Speed's power in his possession, Kratos can run up walls and ram his enemies at great speeds, leaving a trail of fire in his wake.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Norse_Period">Norse Period</span></h3>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Stone_Masons_Chisel_Tip" title="Stone Masons Chisel Tip"><b>Stone Mason Chisel Tip</b></a>: It is a stone used to access <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tunheim" title="Jötunheim">Jötunheim</a>’s hidden gates located on the mountains in <a href="/wiki/Midgard" title="Midgard">Midgard</a>. For this to work, both <strong class="mw-selflink selflink">Kratos</strong> and <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a> must observe carefully on their surroundings. Upon doing so, Kratos needed to use the magical Chisel Tip to open them. To further add to this, the tip was also used to unlock hidden chambers and secret passages.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Witch%27s_Compass" title="Witch's Compass"><b>The Witch's Compass</b></a>: they were a magical talisman granted to Kratos and Atreus by <a href="/wiki/Freya" title="Freya">Freya</a> in her guise as the “<b>Witch of the Woods</b>”. They can then use the compass to lead Kratos, Atreus, and even Mimir to either their main destination or to navigate all across the <a href="/wiki/Nine_Realms" title="Nine Realms">Nine realms</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bifr%C3%B6st" title="Bifröst"><b>Bifröst Lamp</b></a>: a relic that is used by Kratos as a key to travel between the Nine Realms. In order to properly work, the Bifröst lamp needs to be imbued with the Light of <a href="/wiki/Alfheim" title="Alfheim">Alfheim</a>. The lamp is later destroyed in <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_Ragnar%C3%B6k" title="God of War Ragnarök"><i>God of War Ragnarök</i></a>, as <a href="/wiki/Brok" title="Brok">Brok</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sindri" title="Sindri">Sindri</a> use its light to modify the Mystic Gateway, thus making Realm Travel easier.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Unity_Stone" title="Unity Stone"><b>Unity Stone</b></a>: a secret and special travel stone of <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BDr" title="Týr">Týr</a> and is a key item in <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(2018)" title="God of War (2018)">God of War</a></i> <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(2018)" title="God of War (2018)">(2018)</a>. As it turns out, the stone was found after Kratos and Atreus entered the secret chamber of <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BDr%27s_Temple" title="Týr's Temple">Týr's Temple</a>. After Kratos overturns the structure by flipping it upside down, Atreus breaks the <a href="/wiki/Shield" title="Shield">Magic Shield</a> that Týr conjured, allowing Kratos to retrieve the Unity Stone. Upon reaching the end of the path on a branch of Yggdrasil, the stone was used by Kratos and Atreus to survive falling off the path to get to the Realm Between Realms (which they accessed from a Mystic Getaway). Reaching and entering the Jötunheim Tower, the stone was used in bringing the tower back to the <a href="/wiki/Lake_of_Nine" title="Lake of Nine">Lake of Nine</a>. When the tower returned to Midgard, the Unity Stone was left inside, since its purpose has been fulfilled.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mimir" title="Mimir"><b>Head of Mimir</b></a>: Mimir was bound to a tree at the top of Midgard’s mountain, and with Kratos' permission, they decapitated him and took the head with them. Then, they went to the Witch's Cabin to revive the head and then later have a companion to talk with, share stories about the Norse Realm, and eventually lead them to Jötunheim’s hidden gate.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Yggdrasil_Realm_Seeds" title="Yggdrasil Realm Seeds"><b>Yggdrasil Realm Seeds</b></a>: they were introduced in <i>God of War Ragnarök</i> as the only means to unlock access to new Mystic Gateways throughout the Nine Realms. They effectively replace the <a href="/wiki/Bifr%C3%B6st" title="Bifröst">Bifröst Lamp</a>, which was previously used by Kratos to travel through Týr's Temple.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Marbles" title="Marbles"><b>Spiritual Stones</b></a>: Also more commonly known as <b>Marbles</b>, were magical items used by the <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tnar" title="Jötnar">Jötnar</a>. During Ragnarök, <a href="/wiki/Angrboda" title="Angrboda">Angrboda</a> fights alongside with <a href="/wiki/Fenrir" title="Fenrir">Fenrir</a> and used them to save Atreus, Kratos, Freya and Mimir from Asgard's destruction. As Atreus decided to travel outside of the Nine Realms to find other surviving Giants and fully accepts his identity as "<b>Loki</b>", Angrboda gives him her marble so he can visit her at any time.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Draupnir" title="Draupnir">Draupnir</a></b>: a magical ring created by Brok and Sindri and gifted to <a href="/wiki/Odin" title="Odin">Odin</a>. It has the ability to duplicate itself every ninth night, thus dripping eight new rings, although the copies have no value at all. Due to its unique magical capabilities, this legendary ring was eventually given to Kratos as a means to craft the <a href="/wiki/Draupnir_Spear" title="Draupnir Spear">Draupnir Spear</a>, created with the sole purpose of killing Heimdall, the Watchman of the <a href="/wiki/Aesir" title="Aesir">Æsir</a>.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Gjallarhorn" title="Gjallarhorn">Gjallarhorn</a></b>: a mighty horn belonging to one of the Æsir God Heimdall. The horn was obtained after the Greek <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(God)" title="God of War (God)">God of War</a> Kratos killed Heimdall in battle prior to the beginning of Ragnarök and took it for himself. When he presented the horn to his son and allies, they were astonished that the Spartan managed to obtain the horn. Gathering at the Temple of Týr, Kratos brandishes the horn and sent out a massive, earth-shattering horn blast that echoed across all the Nine Realms and ignited all realm Towers, announcing the beginning of the final battle and signalling the armies of <a href="/wiki/Alfheim" title="Alfheim">Alfheim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helheim" title="Helheim">Helheim</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vanaheim" title="Vanaheim">Vanaheim</a> to go to battle. It eventually dissipated, having served its purpose.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Sk%C3%AD%C3%B0bla%C3%B0nir" title="Skíðblaðnir">Skíðblaðnir</a></b>: It is a collapsible, magical boat that was previously owned by the <a href="/wiki/Vanir" title="Vanir">Vanir</a> God Freyr, who then gave it to Kratos to use whenever he needed. Since it was created by the Vanir Gods, it was given the ability to fly and even fold itself when not in use.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationships">Relationships</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Greek_Timeline">Greek Timeline</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a></p><figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/0/0d/Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20240131001859" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="Zeus and Kratos" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Zeus and Kratos.jpg" data-image-key="Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/0/0d/Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20240131001859"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/0/0d/Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20240131001859" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Zeus and Kratos" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/0/0d/Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20240131001859" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Zeus and Kratos.jpg" data-image-key="Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/0/0d/Zeus_and_Kratos.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20240131001859"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos and his father Zeus</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Zeus was Kratos' father but Kratos would not know this until after he waged war against the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Gods" title="Greek Gods">Gods of Olympus</a>. Zeus aided Kratos when he was tasked to kill <a href="/wiki/Ares" title="Ares">Ares</a> by giving him the magic “<a href="/wiki/Zeus%27_Fury" title="Zeus' Fury">Zeus' Fury</a>” and helping Kratos escape the <a href="/wiki/Underworld" title="Underworld">Underworld</a>, though Kratos would never know about the latter. After being infected with the evil fear from <a href="/wiki/Pandora%27s_Box" title="Pandora's Box">Pandora's Box</a>, Zeus became paranoid and fearful of Kratos, believing he would kill him. This was because the Gods wouldn't remove the nightmares from his past, his destructive conquest of Greece, and also cause Kratos would make the Gods pay for the suffering of his mother <a href="/wiki/Callisto" title="Callisto">Callisto</a> and his brother <a href="/wiki/Deimos" title="Deimos">Deimos</a>.
</p><p>As a result, Zeus killed Kratos and also, to make him suffer, he destroyed <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a>. However, these actions would come back to haunt Zeus as Kratos was able to return to life with the aid of <a href="/wiki/Gaia" title="Gaia">Gaia</a>, and after defeating the Sisters of Fate, he went back in time to have his revenge on Zeus. During their final battle, a black smoke (possibly fear) came out of Zeus‘ body and he seemingly allowed himself to get beaten up by Kratos. It is possible that he realized that by causing so much suffering to Greece, he no longer deserved to be King of Olympus and all of the destruction that was caused was because of his own actions was due to himself, not to Kratos. Years later, Kratos regretted killing Zeus, for despite the pain Zeus caused him, vengeance from his death only felt empty. This is shown during his travels in <a href="/wiki/Helheim" title="Helheim">Helheim</a> as the Realm would torture him by making him relieve the moment he killed Zeus.
</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Callisto" title="Callisto">Callisto</a></p><figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/2d/God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20101025010150" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="God of War Ghost of Sparta Playthrough Part 3 397" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="102" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="God of War Ghost of Sparta Playthrough Part 3 397.jpg" data-image-key="God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg" data-relevant="0" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/2d/God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20101025010150"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/2d/God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20101025010150" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="God of War Ghost of Sparta Playthrough Part 3 397" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/2d/God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20101025010150" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="102" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="God of War Ghost of Sparta Playthrough Part 3 397.jpg" data-image-key="God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg" data-relevant="0" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/2d/God_of_War_Ghost_of_Sparta_Playthrough_Part_3_397.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20101025010150"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos and his mother Callisto</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Callisto was Kratos' mother. When Kratos became the new <b>"God of War"</b>, Callisto contacted Kratos through his dreams, begging for aid. Kratos decided to investigate and found her in the Temple of Poseidon. At first he believed her to be a trick of the Gods, but after closely examining her, he realized that it was in fact Callisto. Callisto explains to Kratos that his brother, Deimos, was alive. Kratos is angry that his mother kept this from him, having convinced Kratos in childhood that he had been lost. She explains that she was forbidden from revealing this information to him by Kratos' father. Having never known his father, Kratos expresses confusion. Callisto then reveals to Kratos that Zeus is his father. Callisto then turned into a monster and attacked Kratos, and he was forced to kill her in self-defense. He showed regret and remorse in her death, showing that he still loved her. Callisto was not angry at her son for killing her, and instead thanked him for releasing her from her torment. Even in death, she still loved him and begged the Gods to allow him mercy, and to punish her for his crimes as she blamed herself for all the things he had done. Her death would affect Kratos immensely, as he blamed the Gods for what happened to her and he would make them pay for what they did, something he achieved when he waged war on them.
</p><p>Centuries later, Kratos shows regret at being forced to kill his mother and listing her as some of the many that he lost.
</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Deimos" title="Deimos">Deimos</a></p><figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/7/7f/DeimosKratosStaredown.png/revision/latest?cb=20130908195237" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="DeimosKratosStaredown" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="105" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="DeimosKratosStaredown.png" data-image-key="DeimosKratosStaredown.png" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/7/7f/DeimosKratosStaredown.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20130908195237"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/7/7f/DeimosKratosStaredown.png/revision/latest?cb=20130908195237" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="DeimosKratosStaredown" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/7/7f/DeimosKratosStaredown.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20130908195237" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="105" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="DeimosKratosStaredown.png" data-image-key="DeimosKratosStaredown.png" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/7/7f/DeimosKratosStaredown.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20130908195237"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos and his younger brother Deimos</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Deimos was Kratos' younger brother. When they were young and training to become warriors of Sparta, Kratos was harsh and strict on Deimos, but cared for him deeply, on the inside. When Ares captured Deimos, Kratos tried to save him, only to be swatted away like a fly by Ares. Callisto lied to Kratos, saying that Deimos was dead and it heavily affected him. He vowed never to falter again and, to honor his brother, he gave himself a tattoo in the exact image of his brother's birthmarks. When he learned the truth from his mother, that Deimos was alive, he vowed to save him no matter what. He also did not put up a fight when Deimos angrily attacked him for failing to save him sooner, allowing himself to get badly beaten and injured. When Deimos was killed by Thanatos, Kratos was so enraged that he killed Thanatos without mercy, avenging Deimos' death. He vowed to bring about the Gods' downfall for what they did, a goal he accomplished. During his mental journey, Kratos shows he was still plagued by his brother's death when hearing his <a href="/wiki/The_Pool_of_Blood" title="The Pool of Blood">many victims</a>.
</p><p>Centuries later, Kratos shows regret at failing to protect his brother and listing him as some of the many that he lost. 
</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lysandra" title="Lysandra">Lysandra</a></p><figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/23/Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20130203201202" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="Kratos and Lysandra" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Kratos and Lysandra.jpg" data-image-key="Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/23/Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20130203201202"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/23/Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20130203201202" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Kratos and Lysandra" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/23/Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20130203201202" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Kratos and Lysandra.jpg" data-image-key="Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/2/23/Kratos_and_Lysandra.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20130203201202"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos with his wife Lysandra</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Lysandra was Kratos' first wife. He loved her dearly, and whenever Kratos had enough time to spare from his conquest of Greece, he would go to see her and his daughter Calliope. She loved Kratos in return and was also worried about him, as she believed that his conquest of Greece was going too far and that he was doing it for personal glory rather than for the glory of Sparta. When Kratos accidentally killed her, her death, along with his daughter's, would haunt him for the rest of his life. If one looks at Kratos journal in his ship, he states that no matter how which woman he sleeps with, they all remind him of Lysandra.
</p><p>Centuries later, despite marrying Faye, while traveling in Valhalla, it is shown that Kratos still loved Lysandra and compared her to Faye in terms of character. Having grown to realize the truth of Lysandra's words, one of Kratos's regrets would be that he wasn't a good husband to her, lamenting that he didn't spend enough time with her and regretting his rebuttal of her hopes for him.
</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Calliope" title="Calliope">Calliope</a></p><figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/5/54/Calliope_and_kratos.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20100716003847" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="Calliope and kratos" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="102" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Calliope and kratos.jpg" data-image-key="Calliope_and_kratos.jpg" data-relevant="0" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/5/54/Calliope_and_kratos.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20100716003847"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/5/54/Calliope_and_kratos.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20100716003847" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Calliope and kratos" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/5/54/Calliope_and_kratos.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20100716003847" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="102" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Calliope and kratos.jpg" data-image-key="Calliope_and_kratos.jpg" data-relevant="0" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/5/54/Calliope_and_kratos.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20100716003847"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos reluctantly forced to push Calliope aside in order to save her</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Calliope was Kratos' daughter and, just like his wife, he loved her dearly. He gave her a flute, which Calliope kept and treasured, as it was a memento from him. She kept it even in death. When Kratos was in the Underworld to save Helios, he saw Calliope and wished to be with her, even planning to leave the world at the mercy of Morpheus. Kratos got his chance when Persephone allowed him to enter the Elysium Fields, but only after he sacrificed all of his power first.
</p><p>Calliope was thrilled to see her father again and Kratos, for the first time since being the <b>"Ghost of Sparta"</b>, was happy, and he was seen smiling. However, once Kratos realized the truth- that Persephone was going to destroy the Greek World to have her revenge against the Gods of Olympus, he had no choice but to abandon her as it was the only way to save her. Although he succeeded, he was never allowed to see his daughter again. Calliope was so depressed after her father had abandoned her, that she lost the will to play her flute.
</p><p>Centuries later, despite fathering Atreus, Kratos still thinks about his daughter, although he seldom spoke of her with others. However, in Vanaheim, when Freya accused Kratos of having no idea how much grief he caused her by killing her only child, Kratos replied that he knew exactly how it felt, revealing how he had been tricked into killing his wife and daughter with his own hands, a story that left Freya shocked. Kratos told her that he swore vengeance upon the gods for what they did to his family, but even after destroying all of Olympus, his guilt still remained, hoping to make Freya realize that pursuit of vengeance would not bring her peace. 
</p><p>Whilst exploring Valhalla, Kratos eventually came across Calliope's flute. He then told Mimir of his last memories with Calliope, how she always loved to play a specific tune on her flute whenever he returned home from a military campaign, and how his decision to leave her behind in the Elysium Fields haunted him for much of his life, with his sadness and regret only being eased upon meeting Faye. Kratos reveals that, before meeting Faye, he would have traded all the years that followed his exit from Elysium for mere hours with Calliope. 
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ares" title="Ares">Ares</a>
</p>
<figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/d/d3/Gow2005_53.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20250805145316" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="Gow2005 53" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Gow2005 53.jpg" data-image-key="Gow2005_53.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/d/d3/Gow2005_53.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20250805145316"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/d/d3/Gow2005_53.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20250805145316" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Gow2005 53" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/d/d3/Gow2005_53.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20250805145316" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Gow2005 53.jpg" data-image-key="Gow2005_53.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/d/d3/Gow2005_53.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20250805145316"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos swears revenge to his older half-brother Ares</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Kratos first met <a href="/wiki/Ares" title="Ares">Ares</a> indirectly after the latter and <a href="/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a> arrived in Sparta to take his brother <a href="/wiki/Deimos" title="Deimos">Deimos</a> and get rid of him due to the "<b>Marked Warrior</b>" prophecy, with Ares giving Kratos the scar over his left eye after punching him to prevent the latter from saving Deimos. Kratos would eventually forget this and later served Ares after he saved Kratos from the <a href="/wiki/Barbarians" title="Barbarians">Barbarians</a> during his conquest of <a href="/wiki/Greek_World" title="Greek World">Greece</a>. Ares saw Kratos as the perfect warrior and could use him to take down <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> and become the new ruler of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Olympus</a>. After Kratos killed his enemies to ensure that Kratos would do his bidding, and to make him the ultimate warrior, he forced Kratos to kill innocent people "in the name of Ares". This proved to be easy since Kratos already had a rising bloodlust. His last test was for Kratos to kill his own family, as Ares believed they were holding him back. With them gone, Ares believed Kratos would become stronger - that he would become death itself.
</p><p>Kratos, however, was enraged and disgusted by what Ares made him do and decided to no longer serve him. Ares refused to let go of Kratos and sent the <a href="/wiki/Furies" class="mw-redirect" title="Furies">Furies</a> after him to force him to return. Once Kratos killed the Furies and broke his bond with Ares, his plans were ruined and both had nothing but contempt for each other. Kratos longed for revenge against Ares and finally got his chance when the Gods commanded him to use <a href="/wiki/Pandora%27s_Box" title="Pandora's Box">Pandora's Box</a> to kill him. When Kratos was on the verge of killing Ares, he begged for mercy and justified the murder of his family as trying to make him into a great warrior. Kratos refused to spare Ares and killed him, finally avenging the deaths of his family. Kratos admitted that Ares succeeded in turning Kratos into a great warrior.
</p><p>Even centuries later, Kratos made it clear he did not regret killing Ares despite having grew to regret his many other actions, describing him as a cruel God and showing nothing but bitterness and contempt towards Ares for tricking him into killing his family.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a>
</p>
<figure class="thumb  show-info-icon" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" style="width: 180px"> 	<a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/c/c9/Athena_%285%29.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20191002071920" class="mw-file-description image" style="display: inline-block; position: relative;"><img alt="Athena (5)" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage lazyload" data-image-name="Athena (5).jpg" data-image-key="Athena_%285%29.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/c/c9/Athena_%285%29.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20191002071920"><div style="position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/c/c9/Athena_%285%29.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20191002071920" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Athena (5)" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/c/c9/Athena_%285%29.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20191002071920" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Athena (5).jpg" data-image-key="Athena_%285%29.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/c/c9/Athena_%285%29.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20191002071920"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">Kratos with his older half-sister Athena after accidentally hitting</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Kratos served Athena just like he served all the other Gods of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Olympus</a>, although his relationship with her was perhaps the strongest among the <a href="/wiki/Greek_World" title="Greek World">Greek Pantheon</a>.
