bottom: 0px; right: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%;"><div class="gallery-icon-container view-image"><div class="icon-container view-image" aria-label="view image"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 18 18" width="1em" height="1em"><defs><path id="IconImagesSmall__a" d="M11 15h-.586L3 7.586V7h8v8zm-8 0v-4.586L7.586 15H3zm9-10a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 01-1 1H2a1 1 0 01-1-1V6a1 1 0 011-1h10zm4-4a1 1 0 011 1v10a1 1 0 11-2 0V3H6a1 1 0 110-2h10z"></path></defs><use xlink:href="#IconImagesSmall__a" fill-rule="evenodd"></use></svg></div></div></div></a> 	<noscript><a href="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/12/Angrboda-god-of-war-44771326-2048-1152.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20231224064004" class="mw-file-description image"><img alt="Angrboda-god-of-war-44771326-2048-1152" src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/12/Angrboda-god-of-war-44771326-2048-1152.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20231224064004" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="180" height="101" class="thumbimage" data-image-name="Angrboda-god-of-war-44771326-2048-1152.jpg" data-image-key="Angrboda-god-of-war-44771326-2048-1152.jpg" data-relevant="1" data-src="https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/godofwar/images/1/12/Angrboda-god-of-war-44771326-2048-1152.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/180?cb=20231224064004"></a></noscript> 	<figcaption class="thumbcaption"> 		 			 		 		 		 			<p class="caption">A photograph of Angrboda who would later meet the father of Atreus, Kratos</p> 		 	</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Angrboda is one of the last remaining <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tnar" title="Jötnar">Giants</a>. While Kratos’ direct interactions with her are limited, her significance is felt deeply through her bond with <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a>. Kratos respects her knowledge and the vital role she plays, understanding that her guidance and friendship is crucial for Atreus’ path. This relationship highlights Kratos’ willingness to trust others and despite having had minimal screen-time with her once again during at his travels on restoring the Nine realms, Kratos continues to trusts her and further respects his relationship with the young <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tnar" title="Jötnar">Giantess</a>. Kratos even openly gives her his approval, outright stating that he likes her upon learning of her disciplined personality. 
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p><b>Greek Etymology</b>
</p><p>Kratos (or Cratos) is the son of Pallas and Styx and he has three siblings named Nike ('Victory'), Bia ('Force'), and Zelus ('Glory'). Kratos is characterized as brutal and merciless, repeatedly mocking both Hephaestus and Prometheus and advocating for the use of unnecessary violence. He defends Zeus' oppressive rule and predicts.
</p><p><b>Norse Etymology</b>
</p><p>Kratos is known by the <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tnar" title="Jötnar">Jötnar</a> as <b>Fárbauti</b> (ᚠᚨᚱᛒᚨᚢᛏᛁ), meaning "cruel striker" and interpreted as "lightning". Fárbauti is the Jötunn husband of Laufey and the father of Loki. Fárbauti's character are thought to have been inspired by the observation of the natural phenomena surrounding the appearance of wildfire.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Trivia">Trivia</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General_Facts">General Facts</span></h3>
<ul><li>Kratos is voiced by <a href="/wiki/Terrence_C._Carson" title="Terrence C. Carson">Terrence C. Carson</a> from <i>God of War (<a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(2005)" title="God of War (2005)">2005</a>)</i> to <i>God of War: <a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Ascension" title="God of War: Ascension">Ascension</a></i>, and by <a href="/wiki/Antony_Del_Rio" title="Antony Del Rio">Antony Del Rio</a> as a young Kratos in <i>God of War: <a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Ghost_of_Sparta" title="God of War: Ghost of Sparta">Ghost of Sparta</a></i>. It is until <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Judge" title="Christopher Judge">Christopher Judge</a> then took over the role of a much older Kratos throughout <i>God of War (<a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(2018)" title="God of War (2018)">2018</a>)</i>, <i>God of War <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_Ragnar%C3%B6k" title="God of War Ragnarök">Ragnarök</a> and</i> <i>God of War</i> <i>Ragnarök</i>: <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_Ragnar%C3%B6k:_Valhalla" title="God of War Ragnarök: Valhalla">Valhalla</a></i></li>
<li>According to a <i>God of War III</i> special feature, Kratos stands 8 feet tall.
<ul><li>This was later changed to him being 7 feet 8 inches (2.34 meters) tall in the <a href="/wiki/Greek_World" title="Greek World">Greek Era</a> games, and having his height further reduced to 6 feet 4 inches (1.94 meters) in the <a href="/wiki/Norse_Mythology" title="Norse Mythology">Norse Era</a> games to ease up the motion capture devices so that it is more realistic, as per Christopher Judge's proportions and as per an interview with Axel Grossman.</li></ul></li>
<li>From <i>God of War I</i> to <i>God of War III</i>, Kratos' tattoo gets thinner and thinner and changes slightly in design. In the first game, it stretches on his chest from close to his sternum to past his left nipple. In the second, it is closer to his nipple. In the final game, it does not cover his nipple at all.</li>
<li>Kratos' family is shown to be the only people he has ever truly loved. The only time he has ever been seen smiling was when he found <a href="/wiki/Calliope" title="Calliope">Calliope</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Underworld" title="Underworld">Underworld</a>. Kratos was very distraught when he had to leave her once again.
<ul><li>Later, when he encounters an illusion of his late <a href="/wiki/Lysandra" title="Lysandra">wife</a>, he begs her for forgiveness, something he has never been seen doing before. When he is forced to kill his mother, he is distraught by it. When his younger brother <a href="/wiki/Deimos" title="Deimos">Deimos</a> is killed, Kratos is devastated before he unleashes his rage on <a href="/wiki/Thanatos" title="Thanatos">Thanatos</a> for his actions.</li>
<li>He also cares a lot about his second child, <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a>, protecting him during their journey and although their relationship is initially strained, they grow closer. He is also more concerned about his well-being and temperament, frantically seeking <a href="/wiki/Freya" title="Freya">Freya</a>'s help because he fell ill from his induced rage, he also disciplines his son like any typical father could.</li>
<li>He also cared deeply for his second wife Faye and respected her wisdom, even saying she was better than a god. Flashbacks in <i>God of War: Ragnarök</i> reveal that the two had a very loving relationship and showed Kratos get upset about and have trouble dealing with Faye's impending death.</li></ul></li>
<li>Despite the fact that Kratos' chains from when he very first became a slave to <a href="/wiki/Ares" title="Ares">Ares</a> all those years ago were branded onto his bare flesh, they seemingly were able to be removed, as mentioned above, he wears various things under his chains to keep them off his bare skin. While it is revealed in the <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Fallen_God" title="God of War: Fallen God">God of War: Fallen God</a></i> (Egypt Comics) that the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a> have been following Kratos his entire life after he received them from Ares, it was only the Blades that follow him.</li>
<li>Before the final release <i>God of War (2018)</i>, Kratos' eyes supposedly color green as seen portrait image.</li>
<li>Kratos' <i>God of War (2018)</i> appearance as a tall, muscular, pale man with a thick dark beard, a bald head, tattoos across his head and body and an axe, bears a great resemblance to Grog StrongJaw from Critical role. Grog is a goliath Barbarian often wielding a greataxe, and as a barbarian, he utilizes rage in combat to deal more damage and become more durable. While it's likely a coincidence, many fans of Critical Role and God of War have noticed the resemblance.</li>
<li>Comparing Kratos' character model from <i>God of War III</i> to his character model from <i>God of War 2018</i>, he became noticeably shorter in height in the <i>2018</i> release. While his height has remained inconsistently reported, he was roughly 8 feet tall during the entire Greek saga, though he is roughly 6 feet 6 inches tall in the Norse saga. This is due to the developer's wanting to give Kratos a more realistic appearance.
<ul><li>His entire body shape has also remained slightly inconsistent over the Greek saga, as the size of his head physically was different between each title, as every Greek Saga Games used a different character model for Kratos. His head was cartoonishly small for his III character model. It is unnaturally small in proportion to his shoulders and the rest of his body, while his arms and legs are also too long in comparison to his torso.</li>
<li>His skirt length also changed across the games too, and the chains (and in some games, red gloves worn under the chains) on his forearms changed too. These drastic changes for his character model across the series can be attributed to better hardware and graphics developments being made as the games were being worked on.</li>
<li>Kratos' face looks quite different in complexion and expression to how he looks in <i>God of War II</i>, and so forth. However, the character model used for his appearance in <i>God of War III</i> and <i>God of War: Ascension</i> are the same, with the only major changes to the <i>Ascension</i> model being his tattoo being a very deep red color compared, along with his ashes being whiter, and his expression looking sad at times, with scratches, dirt, and cuts all over his chest. Although, his shin guards also gain a small piece of additional metal on his left leg in II and III.</li>
<li>In <i>God of War III</i> and <i>God of War: Ascension</i>, Kratos' head was slightly shrunk, and it made his head look disproportionately small in comparison to the rest of his body. It is unknown why this change was made, but his head was later made with a much more human-like size in the Norse Era.</li></ul></li>
<li>The Spartan Renegade armor set in <i><a href="https://community.fandom.com/wiki/p:Assassin%27s_Creed_Wiki" class="extiw" title="w:p:Assassin's Creed Wiki">Assassin's Creed Odyssey</a></i> is likely a nod to Kratos and <i>God of War</i> as it features a set of chains wrapped around the protagonist Kassandra's arms in a similar fashion to Kratos.</li>
<li>Kratos never actually says his own name or introduces himself to anyone in all of his appearances.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_Greek_Era">In Greek Era</span></h3>
<ul><li>Kratos kills about one God in every game (a total of 14 <a href="/wiki/Gods" title="Gods">Gods</a>), with the most notable exception being <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_III" title="God of War III">God of War III</a></i>, where he kills a total of 7 Gods.</li>
<li>It is unknown why many characters, even if they are fully aware of Kratos' <a href="/wiki/Demigod" title="Demigod">demigod</a> status, still call him a <a href="/wiki/Greek_Mortals" title="Greek Mortals">mortal</a>. It could be that they did not feel like calling him a demigod, or they use it as an insult, making Kratos feel that he is beneath them.</li>
<li>Prior to being revealed to be the "<b>Marked Warrior</b>", who the prophecy foretold the end of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Olympus</a> would be at his hand, Kratos was said to be 'marked warrior' by many individuals. The <a href="/wiki/Village_Oracle" title="Village Oracle">village Oracle</a> who cursed him when she bonded the ashes of his family to his skin stated that the mark of his deeds would be visible to everyone, and a spider he encountered during his quest to destroy the <a href="/wiki/Ambrosia" title="Ambrosia">Ambrosia</a> to stop the followers of Ares from reviving him stated he is a mortal marked with destruction.</li>
<li>By technicality, Kratos managed to free himself from his past in <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Chains_of_Olympus" title="God of War: Chains of Olympus">God of War: Chains of Olympus</a></i>. When he gave up his weapons, powers, and abilities, Kratos' tattoo and pale skin were also removed, thus granting him amnesty. However, he was forced to regain everything at the cost of his daughter, <a href="/wiki/Calliope" title="Calliope">Calliope</a>.</li>
<li>In all of the main installments of the <a href="/wiki/God_of_War_(series)" title="God of War (series)"><i>God of War</i> series</a>, Kratos is killed at some point by impalement through his abdomen. The first time was from a stone pillar being hurled at him by Ares, the second time was from Zeus driving the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a> into his chest, and the final time was him committing suicide by using the Blade of Olympus once again.</li>
<li>Kratos has killed both of his parents in his quests: He is forced to reluctantly kill his mother <a href="/wiki/Callisto" title="Callisto">Callisto</a> in God of War: <i>Ghost of Sparta</i>, and brutally kill his father <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> in <i>God of War III</i>.</li>
<li>Most of Kratos' actions during the series were driven by rage and vengeance. Some exceptions are when he was searching for the Ambrosia to save his daughter, when saving his brother Deimos while ignoring any and all godly warnings, and when trying to prevent <a href="/wiki/Pandora" title="Pandora">Pandora</a> from sacrificing herself in the <a href="/wiki/Flame_of_Olympus" title="Flame of Olympus">Flame of Olympus</a>, and later to spread his second wife's ashes on the highest peak in the <a href="/wiki/Nine_Realms" title="Nine Realms">Nine Realms</a> (which turned out to be in <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tunheim" title="Jötunheim">Jötunheim</a>), accompanied by his son <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a>.</li>
<li>Kratos has killed three different people directly from bashing their faces in with something (or his bare hands). Those being, slamming a huge metal door into <a href="/wiki/Theseus" title="Theseus">Theseus</a>' head over and over, punching <a href="/wiki/Hercules" title="Hercules">Hercules</a> in the face with the <a href="/wiki/Nemean_Cestus" title="Nemean Cestus">Nemean Cestus</a>, and finally, Kratos punching Zeus in the face with his bare fists until it kills him from blunt trauma to the head.</li>
<li>In the series, when Kratos encounters any of his half-siblings or cousins, he initially does not intend to battle them but is ultimately forced to when they either provoke him or challenge him. Prime examples include both <a href="/wiki/Perseus" title="Perseus">Perseus</a>, Theseus and Hercules.</li>
<li>It is never clearly mentioned how long Kratos reigned as a God, but judging from the fact that it has been over 4603 days and has spent a total of 12.6 years of working. This implies that 12.6 years have passed between <i>God of War</i> and <i>God of War III</i>.
<ul><li>With this information, one can assume that Kratos was born between 510 BC ~ 500 BC and that <i>God of War III</i> finished around 470 BC ~ 460 BC, as he spent about 12 years as a God, 10 as a slave to Olympus, and even before. Judging by his voice pattern and physical appearance, his age in <i>God of War III</i> is estimated around 40 ~ almost 50 years old.</li>
<li>Many suggests that Kratos was actually born between 230 BC ~ 220 BC and that <i>God of War III</i> finishes between 190 BC ~ 180 BC.</li></ul></li>
<li>Kratos is also seen having sad expressions. In <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War:_Ascension" title="God of War: Ascension">God of War: Ascension</a></i>, Kratos is seen desolated as he's trapped in the <a href="/wiki/The_Furies" title="The Furies">Furies</a>' illusions. Later, he's seen genuinely sad by the fact he has to kill <a href="/wiki/Orkos" title="Orkos">Orkos</a> to free himself from Ares.</li>
<li>Kratos' fighting style changes throughout the game as he becomes more and more experienced. In <i>God of War: Ascension, h</i>e uses the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a> to perform grabs while in all other games, he prefers to overpower his enemies by grabbing them with his hands. In <i>God of War III</i>, many of his moves are slightly faster than the older games.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Amazons" title="Amazons">Amazonian Warrior</a> from <i>God of War: Ascension</i> was based on drawings for a character that was meant to be Kratos' daughter. "With the mysterious fate of Kratos at the end of <i>God of War III</i>, we knew we wanted to give him a successor - a new hero who would go looking for him," Juan writes. "Not unlike the most recent entry in the series, we imagined that he had a hidden daughter and began sketching ideas of what she would look like"</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_Norse_Era">In Norse Era</span></h3>
<ul><li>Because of <a href="/wiki/Laufey" title="Laufey">Faye</a>, Kratos is knowledgeable of some of the <a href="/wiki/Norse_Gods" title="Norse Gods">Norse Gods</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Thor" title="Thor">Thor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Odin" title="Odin">Odin</a>. However, he is far less knowledgeable than either <a href="/wiki/Atreus" title="Atreus">Atreus</a> or Mimir, and will occasionally ask them for information: this serves as a means for the game to share the world's lore with the player.</li>
<li>After leaving the <a href="/wiki/Greek_World" title="Greek World">Greek World</a> following all the chaos he has caused there, Kratos begins to develop some sort of loathing towards his "<b>Ghost of Sparta</b><i>"</i> moniker and even warns Mimir when he addresses him as such.</li></ul>
<ul><li>While on the boat with Atreus, if <a href="/wiki/Mimir" title="Mimir">Mimir</a> is not present by this time, Kratos will tell stories he heard from a famous storyteller, who is highly implied to be Aesop, a famous Greek storyteller. Many of these stories do eventually foreshadow moments in the game and parallel other moments in the series. Atreus stated that Kratos is not a good storyteller and while he does have some negative complaints towards the stories he tells, he repeatedly states Kratos' skill outright is bad. The night before Kratos launches an assault on <a href="/wiki/Asgard" title="Asgard">Asgard</a>, he tells one more story to Atreus in his tent, but only tells half of it, later finishing it after the war is won. This story is also one of Aesop's fables.
<ul><li>The story of <i>The Hare and Tortoise</i> was very similar to the fight between Kratos and <a href="/wiki/Hermes" title="Hermes">Hermes</a>. Like the hare in the story, Hermes is too confident of his speed and constantly mocks Kratos' inability to catch him. Like the Tortoise, Kratos remains steady and determined to defeat him and becomes the winner between the two.</li>
<li><i>The Horse and the Hunter</i> story is similar to Kratos battle against the <a href="/wiki/Barbarians" title="Barbarians">Barbarians</a>. A horse allows himself to be made into a hunter’s mount in order to kill his enemy, a stag, but is denied his freedom afterwards. The story shares similarities with Kratos pledging himself to Ares in a bid to destroy his enemies, which included the <a href="/wiki/Alrik" title="Alrik">Barbarian King</a>, and sacrificing his freedom for the sake of revenge.</li>
<li><i>The Young Crab and his Mother</i> story mirrors the relationship between Kratos and his son. Kratos often verbally reminds Atreus to be a better person than him. However, as in the story where the mother crab cannot teach her son how to walk forwards, Kratos struggles to teach his son compassion and discipline when Kratos' own life has been marked by so much suffering and death.</li>
<li><i>The Thief and His Mother</i> parallels the relationship between <a href="/wiki/Freya" title="Freya">Freya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baldur" title="Baldur">Baldur</a>. In the story, a thief is arrested and sentenced to death and as a last request, he wanted to see his mother before his execution. When she came to see him, he angrily bit off his mother's ear and proclaimed that it was her fault for never disciplining him when he first started stealing. In <i>God of War (2018)</i>, Freya loved Baldur more than anything and when she learned from the norns that he would die a needless death, she made him immortal but it deprived him of every sensation in the process. Baldur grew to resent his mother for doing this and would eventually try to murder her for causing a century of misery.</li>
<li><i>The Frog and Scorpion</i> is a more overt example as both Kratos and Faye compared the <a href="/wiki/Gods" title="Gods">Gods</a> to the titular scorpion. As both believe the only nature of a God is to be praised for dooming others.</li>
<li><i>The Old Man and Death</i> mirrors Kratos' life up to the point that he travelled to <a href="/wiki/Midgard" title="Midgard">Midgard</a> and met Faye. In the story, an old man had the duty of chopping wood for his village, carrying the logs on his back and manually transporting them every day. Over time, the heavy burden weakened the man, who became resentful and miserable as years passed, eventually throwing the logs down and calling for Death to take him. When Death arrived, he asked the man why he had called him, to which the old man had a change of heart, and instead asked Death to help him carry the logs so he could finish his journey.
<ul><li>In Greece, Kratos' duties involved fighting for <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a> and serving the <a href="/wiki/Olympians" title="Olympians">Olympians</a>. As years passed, the demands of the gods became more difficult, and as Kratos lost the people he loved as a result, he became more and more unstable as his hate began to consume him. Eventually, he reached his breaking point, when, after losing his entire family to the Gods, <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> betrayed him, killing him and laying waste to his army and all of Sparta. Kratos then 'threw down the logs' and declared war on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Olympus</a>, unable to bear the weight of their demands any longer. After slaughtering the Gods and laying waste to his homeland, Kratos wished for death, but was unable to die, and travelled to the Norse lands to start a new life, still ridden with hate and guilt, begging for release. After meeting Faye and fathering Atreus, Kratos had a new purpose in life, and no longer wished to die, instead choosing to keep living in order to protect his new family and friends.</li>
<li>This story also reflects the change of heart Kratos had during the assault on Asgard, that by opening his heart to the innocent casualties of Asgard and choosing for fight for justice rather than vengeance, he ultimately averted his own death prophecy.</li></ul></li></ul></li>
<li>When speaking with Freya about <a href="/wiki/Helheim" title="Helheim">Helheim</a>, he implies to her that he is familiar with another afterlife, a reference to him traveling through the <a href="/wiki/Underworld" title="Underworld">Underworld</a> several times during his quests.</li>
<li>While in <a href="/wiki/Hel" title="Hel">Hel</a>, Kratos witness a reenactment of his final battle with Zeus at the end of <i>God of War III.</i> However, Kratos' voice of him screaming at Zeus are redone with <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Judge" title="Christopher Judge">Christopher Judge</a>'s voice instead of <a href="/wiki/Terrence_C._Carson" title="Terrence C. Carson">Terrence C. Carson</a>. The blades that Kratos throws away in the scene were also changed to the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a> instead of Blades of Exile.</li>
<li>While in <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BDr%27s_Temple" title="Týr's Temple">Týr's chambers</a>, he finds a vase containing Lemnian wine, from Lemnos, a Greek Island near his birthplace in <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a>. He and Atreus drink the centuries-old wine and Atreus is disgusted by it, while Kratos enjoys it.
<ul><li>Also in Týr's chambers, he destroys a vase. This vase is painted with Kratos standing over a pile of bodies, holding the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Exile" title="Blades of Exile">Blades of Exile</a> and screaming into the air as blood drips from the blades. He smashes it before Atreus can see it, so his past is not revealed to him.</li></ul></li></ul>
<ul><li>Kratos tells Atreus that he has met many spirits before. He could be talking about <a href="/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a>, or the many times he has faced undead foes like Alrik.</li>
<li>As part of his Greek culture and of his past, he treats Atreus in a different way than he did with his daughter Calliope, as Spartans were taught how to fight and survive at a young age with a 'sink or swim' philosophy. When asked about it by Atreus, Kratos states that he did not raise his son that way not because he thought him weak, but because he believes he didn't have to endure it like his father did, much to Arteus' thanks.</li>
<li>When he reveals his past to Atreus, he mentions that he has killed those who were deserving, such as Ares, <a href="/wiki/Persephone" title="Persephone">Persephone</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Thanatos" title="Thanatos">Thanatos</a>, while he has slaughtered those who were not, such as the countless innocents he killed while serving Ares, including his daughter and wife.</li>
<li>During some side missions, Kratos and Atreus learn of people killing their fathers, which Atreus finds surprising. Ironically, this was the case with Kratos and Zeus.
<ul><li>In that side mission, Kratos didn't face the ghost of the father as he told his tale, possibly still ashamed of what he did.</li></ul></li>
<li>Many times through his adventure with Atreus, he reminds his son of the danger of the Gods, that there are no good Gods.</li>
<li>In <i>God of War (2018)</i>, the scar on Kratos’ back is white like the rest of his skin, but in <i>God of War <a href="/wiki/Ragnar%C3%B6k" title="Ragnarök">Ragnarök</a></i>, it is red like his tattoo, most easily seen in the second Faye dream sequence.</li>
<li>Interestingly, Kratos is only tortured by his vision of killing <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Helheim" title="Helheim">Helheim</a>, despite the countless crimes and atrocities he committed including the killing of his own wife and daughter. It might be because Kratos had already forgiven himself for those sins while he was tormented by fear, leaving the murder of Zeus as the only sin Helheim can punish him with, since Kratos himself is now a father.</li>
<li>After seeing Zeus for the first time in Helheim, Kratos seemingly reacts with fear upon seeing his father after decades had passed since the former's death. This could hint that despite Zeus being dead for a very long time, he continues to haunt Kratos subconsciously, being a continual reminder of his greatest failure and his lust for revenge leaving him with nothing, thus giving some form of "last laugh" over Kratos.</li></ul>
<ul><li>Interestingly, when Mimir tells the story of <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6rmungandr" title="Jörmungandr">Jörmungandr</a> being sent back in time Kratos reacts with disbelief, claiming it as madness, despite the fact that he himself has travelled through time in the past and has seen multiple instances of time manipulation in his life.</li>
<li>Interestingly, Mimir himself originally didn't believe the story of Kratos traveling back in time, saying that it had to be exaggerated. Upon telling the story, both Freya and Mimir call it the most dangerous action they both have ever heard.</li>
<li>Kratos believes that fate is a lie, however he is unaware of the '<b>Marked Warrior</b>' prophecy, which predicted his destruction of Olympus and the Gods exactly. His actions within the Norse Realm were also predicted by the <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6tnar" title="Jötnar">Jötnar</a> race long before he ever arrived, showing that predetermined destinies are actually true and Kratos has been unwittingly fulfilling prophecies all of his life. Kratos proves that he is aware of this prophecy when he tells Freya about the kidnapping of Deimos by the prophecy that was uttered, and when he tells Mimir about how Alethia helped him stop Ares because she had a vision of the destruction of Olympus at the hands of the God of War who turned out to be Kratos himself.</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt">
</li><li class="mw-empty-elt">
</li><li>When Kratos confessed to Atreus that he is a God, many took it to mean that he only has divine blood, but due to his ability to kill the Nordic Gods without the <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>, he is likely referring to him being a full God.</li>
<li>When Mimir asks Kratos about having any pre-Fimbulwinter cravings, Kratos simply replies with "olives," which Mimir has never heard of, being that olives originate from the Mediterranean area.</li>
<li>Mimir asks about the Battle of Thermopylae, which he heard about during his traveling years, and whether Kratos fought there. Kratos reveals that for many years he regretted not being one of the 300 <a href="/wiki/Spartan" title="Spartan">Spartans</a> that died alongside <a href="/wiki/Spear_of_Leonidas" title="Spear of Leonidas">King Leonidas</a>, but no longer felt that way.</li>
<li>Kratos does not appear to take care of his weapons and armor. When asked about the old armor's that <a href="/wiki/Brok" title="Brok">Brok</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sindri" title="Sindri">Sindri</a> forged for him, Kratos mentions that he used all of them. Both Brok and Sindri tell Kratos to be more careful with his <a href="/wiki/Armor_Sets" title="Armor Sets">gear</a> and criticizes him for breaking the armors they made for him as well as the condition of the <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_Axe" title="Leviathan Axe">Leviathan Axe</a>. This would also explain why Kratos is missing all the weapons from his past games as they either break from him using them so much or he simply throws them away when done with them.
<ul><li>Interestingly, Kratos views faulty weaponry as a hindrance in battle. When Atreus breaks part of his quiver strap in God of War (2018), he immediately gets it fixed with an arrowhead of the mistletoe arrow, even though Atreus admitted he was fine with the condition.</li></ul></li>
<li>Despite being shown wearing a fur cloak in the promotional posters and opening sequence of the game for <i>God of War</i> <i>Ragnarök,</i>  he loses this cloak during the initial struggle with Freya and never replaces it. However, with the release of the game’s New Game Plus update, a new armor set, the <a href="/wiki/Armor_Sets_(Ragnar%C3%B6k)" title="Armor Sets (Ragnarök)">Black Bear Set</a>, was added that bears the cloak and is equipped at the start of the NG+ game.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Guest_Appearances">Guest Appearances</span></h3>
<ul><li>Kratos makes a guest appearance in <i>Soulcalibur: Broken Destiny</i>. He fights with the <a href="/wiki/Blades_of_Chaos" title="Blades of Chaos">Blades of Chaos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blade_of_Olympus" title="Blade of Olympus">Blade of Olympus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Icarus_Wings" title="Icarus Wings">Icarus' Wings</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poseidon%27s_Rage" title="Poseidon's Rage">Poseidon's Rage</a>.</li>
<li>Kratos also makes a guest appearance in the PS3 golf game, <i>Everybody's Golf: World Tour</i>. Playing with the 'Clubs of Olympus', Kratos is portrayed being quite rude to his caddy, blaming all his bogies and missed shots on <a href="/wiki/Sisters_of_Fate" title="Sisters of Fate">The Sisters of Fate</a>.</li>
<li>The PS3 exclusive kart racing game <i>ModNation</i> offers Kratos, and his <i>Kart of Chaos</i>, as a playable character when pre-ordering. Kratos, along with other pre-order incentives, were made available worldwide.</li>
<li>In 2009's Game of the Year <i>LitteBigPlanet</i>, there is a rare character costume of Kratos, as well as <a href="/wiki/Medusa" title="Medusa">Medusa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pandora%27s_Guardian" title="Pandora's Guardian">Pandora's Guardian</a>.</li>
<li>Kratos appears in the PlayStation Three and PlayStation Vita versions of the 2011 game <i><a href="/wiki/Mortal_Kombat" class="mw-redirect" title="Mortal Kombat">Mortal Kombat</a>,</i> with his own set of moves, and a personal God of War battle arena. He is not, however, a part of the storyline.</li>
<li>In the game <i>Age of Mythology</i> and its expansion, <i>The Titans</i>, there is a character named Kastor. Interestingly, his name can be arranged into Kratos. His background shares slight similarities to Kratos', as he too distrusted the <a href="/wiki/Gods" title="Gods">Gods</a> and sided with the <a href="/wiki/Titans" title="Titans">Titans</a> while, unbeknownst to him, being used as a pawn.
<ul><li>Kratos is one of the playable characters in the multi-franchise fighter <i>PlayStation All-Stars: Battle Royale</i>. Along with him, God of War-franchise member <a href="/wiki/Hades" title="Hades">Hades</a> also makes an appearance, albeit as a background character. <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> also appears as a playable DLC character in the game.</li>
<li><i>A God of War</i> themed event was added in <i>Destiny of Spirits</i>, alongside advanced summons which had Kratos in it.</li>
<li>Kratos appears in the PlayStation 3/4/Vita versions of <i><a href="/wiki/Kratos_(Shovel_Knight)" title="Kratos (Shovel Knight)">Shovel Knight</a></i>.
<ul><li>The developers of Shovel Knight as well as the God of War director, Cory Barlog, have both confirmed that both universes are in fact one and the same.<sup id="cite_ref-YachtClubGames_Tweet_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-YachtClubGames_Tweet-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Comic-Con_2018_Shovel_Knight_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Comic-Con_2018_Shovel_Knight-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li>Norse Kratos appears as a <a href="https://fortnite.fandom.com/wiki/Kratos" class="extiw" title="w:c:Fortnite:Kratos">skin</a> in <a href="/wiki/Fortnite" title="Fortnite">Fortnite</a>.</li></ul></li>
<li>Kratos appears in 'bot form <i>Astro Bot</i> with the moniker "Dad of Boy." His description reads "Greece? That's ancient history!"</li></ul>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Photo_Mode">Photo Mode</span></h3>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Concept_Arts">Concept Arts</span></h3>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cosplay_Guides">Cosplay Guides</span></h3>
